metadata.bible_text: Psalm 79:13 (primary), with references to Psalms 22, 50, 100, and 106
metadata.sermon_start_end: The famous Dr. Samuel Johnson, author of the first major English dictionary, renowned conversationalist, wit, and man about town, was also a man of deep Biblical faith. When after heroic labors the Great Lexicographer finally finished his Dictionary, he sent the last sheet of manuscript round to the publisher [...] Save us, O LORD our God … that we may give thanks to thy holy name and glory in thy praise. Blessed be the LORD, the God of Israel, from everlasting to everlasting! Let all the people say, ‘Amen!’ Praise the LORD!

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon fails to focus on one specific Bible passage. While Psalm 79:13 is the header, the preacher treats 'thanksgiving' as a general biblical theme, jumping between various Psalms (22, 50, 100, 106). It lacks the 'NOWHERE else' specificity Dekker demands.
quotes: Nowhere is the motif of thanksgiving and praise to God more conspicuous than in the Psalms.
Surely this is what the Psalms teach us about our covenant relationship to God.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Restrict the sermon to the specific context of Psalm 79. This Psalm is a communal lament about the destruction of Jerusalem; giving thanks from a position of 'misery' (the ruins) is the unique point that is lost when jumping to the 'joyful' Psalm 100.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: There is no evidence of Hebrew/Greek study or historical-critical exegesis. The preacher uses the English text to illustrate a theme rather than uncovering what the text meant for the first readers. The specific historical situation of Psalm 79 (the exile/destruction) is ignored.
quotes: The theme of gratitude is the cantus firmus, the constant undergirding melody of the Biblical song.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Identify the original context of Psalm 79:13. It is a promise of future praise made by a people under God's wrath. Explain how 'the flock of thy pasture' functions in a context of national defeat.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is somewhat concrete regarding the 'zeitgeist' (the secularization of Thanksgiving cards), but it remains largely in the realm of general psychological attitudes and 'art forms' rather than the specific claim of the text on the hearer's life.
quotes: I went into a shop last week to buy Thanksgiving cards... All references to God had been excised.
Being thankful is to some extent an art form.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond 'gratitude as a way of life' to the specific application of praising God when there is no harvest—connecting the 'misery' of the original text to contemporary crises.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon is a thematic essay. Exposition and application are not 'mixed' because there is very little actual exposition of the text's mechanics. The hearer is not 'drawn into the text' but rather into the preacher's anecdotes.
quotes: A few years ago one of my most beloved seminary professors died...
I went into a shop last week...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Use the biblical imagery (e.g., 'the flock') as the vehicle for the contemporary application throughout the sermon, rather than alternating between personal stories and proof-texting.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon explicitly deals with gratitude and touches on misery (the 'hard things of existence'). However, misery is treated more as 'adversity' or 'hardship' rather than the theological 'misery before God' (sin/wrath) that Dekker/Heidelberg Catechism implies.
quotes: The life of thankfulness — Biblically speaking — is lived in view of the hard things of existence.
His faithfulness in spite of our unfaithfulness is told and retold.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'misery' aspect. Instead of 'adversity,' address the 'iniquity' mentioned in Psalm 106:43 to show that redemption is a necessity, not just a 'help in time of need'.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The 'two ways' are entirely absent. There is no sense of the possibility of being lost, either temporally or eternally. The tone is universally inclusive, fitting for an interfaith service but failing Dekker's requirement for the 'seriousness of life design'.
quotes: I suspect most of you have made the extra effort to be here because you want God to be in the equation.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Introduce the alternative to the 'thankful life.' What is the 'destruction' (Thesis 6) that awaits the ungrateful or those who refuse to acknowledge the Giver?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: As an interfaith service sermon, Christ is completely absent. According to Dekker, this makes the sermon 'theologically nonsensical' as Christ is the only valid telos and the only way to speak of God truly.
quotes: The meaning of life is grounded in the praise of God.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: According to Dekker's Thesis 7, Christ cannot be silenced. The preacher must show how Christ is the 'One Lord' who enables this gratitude, even if it creates tension in an interfaith setting.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 13.5 minutes, the sermon is significantly below the 20-minute minimum. It lacks the 'breadth' required for 'depth'.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical portion and the theological depth of the 'three parts' to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria on almost every fundamental level. It is a thematic speech on the virtue of gratitude rather than an exposition of a specific Bible passage. It lacks a single-text focus, ignores the original linguistic and historical context, and entirely omits Christ as the telos. The 'two ways' are absent, resulting in a message that lacks the urgency of revelation.
strengths: Adequate observation of the secular zeitgeist regarding the 'generic' nature of modern gratitude.
Clear thematic structure that moves from human 'art form' to God as the recipient of praise.
weaknesses: Failure to adhere to a single pericope (Thesis 1.3).
Absence of the 'two ways'/seriousness of being lost (Thesis 6).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the sense of Dekker's definition. It is a religious address on a biblical theme. By omitting Christ and the specific exegetical weight of a single text, it fails to function as the 'Word of God' in the proclamatory sense.
